author: Grimms
text: One summer"s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might.

author: Grimms
text: Then came a peasant woman down the street crying: "Good jams, cheap!

author: Grimms
text: Good jams, cheap!"

author: Grimms
text: This rang pleasantly in the tailor"s ears; he stretched his delicate head out of the window, and called: "Come up here, dear woman; here you will get rid of your goods."

author: Grimms
text: The woman came up the three steps to the tailor with her heavy basket, and he made her unpack all the pots for him.

author: Grimms
text: He inspected each one, lifted it up, put his nose to it, and at length said: "The jam seems to me to be good, so weigh me out four ounces, dear woman, and if it is a quarter of a pound that is of no consequence."

author: Grimms
text: The woman who had hoped to find a good sale, gave him what he desired, but went away quite angry and grumbling.

author: Grimms
text: "Now, this jam shall be blessed by God," cried the little tailor, "and give me health and strength"; so he brought the bread out of the cupboard, cut himself a piece right across the loaf and spread the jam over it.

author: Grimms
text: "This won"t taste bitter," said he, "but I will just finish the jacket before I take a bite."

author: Grimms
text: He laid the bread near him, sewed on, and in his joy, made bigger and bigger stitches.

author: Grimms
text: In the meantime the smell of the sweet jam rose to where the flies were sitting in great numbers, and they were attracted and descended on it in hosts.

author: Grimms
text: "Hi! who invited you?" said the little tailor, and drove the unbidden guests away.

author: Grimms
text: The flies, however, who understood no German, would not be turned away, but came back again in ever-increasing companies.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor at last lost all patience, and drew a piece of cloth from the hole under his work-table, and saying: "Wait, and I will give it to you," struck it mercilessly on them.

author: Grimms
text: When he drew it away and counted, there lay before him no fewer than seven, dead and with legs stretched out.

author: Grimms
text: "Are you a fellow of that sort?" said he, and could not help admiring his own bravery.

author: Grimms
text: "The whole town shall know of this!"

author: Grimms
text: And the little tailor hastened to cut himself a girdle, stitched it, and embroidered on it in large letters: "Seven at one stroke!"

author: Grimms
text: "What, the town!" he continued, "the whole world shall hear of it!" and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb"s tail.

author: Grimms
text: The tailor put on the girdle, and resolved to go forth into the world, because he thought his workshop was too small for his valour.

author: Grimms
text: Before he went away, he sought about in the house to see if there was anything which he could take with him; however, he found nothing but an old cheese, and that he put in his pocket.

author: Grimms
text: In front of the door he observed a bird which had caught itself in the thicket.

author: Grimms
text: It had to go into his pocket with the cheese.

author: Grimms
text: Now he took to the road boldly, and as he was light and nimble, he felt no fatigue.

author: Grimms
text: The road led him up a mountain, and when he had reached the highest point of it, there sat a powerful giant looking peacefully about him.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor went bravely up, spoke to him, and said: "Good day, comrade, so you are sitting there overlooking the wide-spread world!

author: Grimms
text: I am just on my way thither, and want to try my luck.

author: Grimms
text: Have you any inclination to go with me?"

author: Grimms
text: The giant looked contemptuously at the tailor, and said: "You ragamuffin!

author: Grimms
text: You miserable creature!"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, indeed?" answered the little tailor, and unbuttoned his coat, and showed the giant the girdle, "there may you read what kind of a man I am!"

author: Grimms
text: The giant read: "Seven at one stroke," and thought that they had been men whom the tailor had killed, and began to feel a little respect for the tiny fellow.

author: Grimms
text: Nevertheless, he wished to try him first, and took a stone in his hand and squeezed it together so that water dropped out of it.

author: Grimms
text: "Do that likewise," said the giant, "if you have strength."

author: Grimms
text: "Is that all?" said the tailor, "that is child"s play with us!" and put his hand into his pocket, brought out the soft cheese, and pressed it until the liquid ran out of it.

author: Grimms
text: "Faith," said he, "that was a little better, wasn"t it?"

author: Grimms
text: The giant did not know what to say, and could not believe it of the little man.

author: Grimms
text: Then the giant picked up a stone and threw it so high that the eye could scarcely follow it.

author: Grimms
text: "Now, little mite of a man, do that likewise," "Well thrown," said the tailor, "but after all the stone came down to earth again; I will throw you one which shall never come back at all," and he put his hand into his pocket, took out the bird, and threw it into the air.

author: Grimms
text: The bird, delighted with its liberty, rose, flew away and did not come back.

author: Grimms
text: "How does that shot please you, comrade?" asked the tailor.

author: Grimms
text: "You can certainly throw," said the giant, "but now we will see if you are able to carry anything properly."

author: Grimms
text: He took the little tailor to a mighty oak tree which lay there felled on the ground, and said: "If you are strong enough, help me to carry the tree out of the forest."

author: Grimms
text: "Readily," answered the little man; "take you the trunk on your shoulders, and I will raise up the branches and twigs; after all, they are the heaviest."

author: Grimms
text: The giant took the trunk on his shoulder, but the tailor seated himself on a branch, and the giant, who could not look round, had to carry away the whole tree, and the little tailor into the bargain: he behind, was quite merry and happy, and whistled the song: "Three tailors rode forth from the gate," as if carrying the tree were child"s play.

author: Grimms
text: The giant, after he had dragged the heavy burden part of the way, could go no further, and cried: "Hark you, I shall have to let the tree fall!"

author: Grimms
text: The tailor sprang nimbly down, seized the tree with both arms as if he had been carrying it, and said to the giant: "You are such a great fellow, and yet cannot even carry the tree!"

author: Grimms
text: They went on together, and as they passed a cherry-tree, the giant laid hold of the top of the tree where the ripest fruit was hanging, bent it down, gave it into the tailor"s hand, and bade him eat.

author: Grimms
text: But the little tailor was much too weak to hold the tree, and when the giant let it go, it sprang back again, and the tailor was tossed into the air with it.

author: Grimms
text: When he had fallen down again without injury, the giant said: "What is this?

author: Grimms
text: Have you not strength enough to hold the weak twig?"

author: Grimms
text: "There is no lack of strength," answered the little tailor.

author: Grimms
text: "Do you think that could be anything to a man who has struck down seven at one blow?

author: Grimms
text: I leapt over the tree because the huntsmen are shooting down there in the thicket.

author: Grimms
text: Jump as I did, if you can do it."

author: Grimms
text: The giant made the attempt but he could not get over the tree, and remained hanging in the branches, so that in this also the tailor kept the upper hand.

author: Grimms
text: The giant said: "If you are such a valiant fellow, come with me into our cavern and spend the night with us."

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor was willing, and followed him.

author: Grimms
text: When they went into the cave, other giants were sitting there by the fire, and each of them had a roasted sheep in his hand and was eating it.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor looked round and thought: "It is much more spacious here than in my workshop."

author: Grimms
text: The giant showed him a bed, and said he was to lie down in it and sleep.

author: Grimms
text: The bed, however, was too big for the little tailor; he did not lie down in it, but crept into a corner.

author: Grimms
text: When it was midnight, and the giant thought that the little tailor was lying in a sound sleep, he got up, took a great iron bar, cut through the bed with one blow, and thought he had finished off the grasshopper for good.

author: Grimms
text: With the earliest dawn the giants went into the forest, and had quite forgotten the little tailor, when all at once he walked up to them quite merrily and boldly.

author: Grimms
text: The giants were terrified, they were afraid that he would strike them all dead, and ran away in a great hurry.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor went onwards, always following his own pointed nose.

author: Grimms
text: After he had walked for a long time, he came to the courtyard of a royal palace, and as he felt weary, he lay down on the grass and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
text: Whilst he lay there, the people came and inspected him on all sides, and read on his girdle: "Seven at one stroke."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said they, "what does the great warrior want here in the midst of peace?

author: Grimms
text: He must be a mighty lord."

author: Grimms
text: They went and announced him to the king, and gave it as their opinion that if war should break out, this would be a weighty and useful man who ought on no account to be allowed to depart.

author: Grimms
text: The counsel pleased the king, and he sent one of his courtiers to the little tailor to offer him military service when he awoke.

author: Grimms
text: The ambassador remained standing by the sleeper, waited until he stretched his limbs and opened his eyes, and then conveyed to him this proposal.

author: Grimms
text: "For this very reason have I come here," the tailor replied, "I am ready to enter the king"s service."

author: Grimms
text: He was therefore honourably received, and a special dwelling was assigned him.

author: Grimms
text: The soldiers, however, were set against the little tailor, and wished him a thousand miles away.

author: Grimms
text: "What is to be the end of this?" they said among themselves.

author: Grimms
text: "If we quarrel with him, and he strikes about him, seven of us will fall at every blow; not one of us can stand against him."

author: Grimms
text: They came therefore to a decision, betook themselves in a body to the king, and begged for their dismissal.

author: Grimms
text: "We are not prepared," said they, "to stay with a man who kills seven at one stroke."

author: Grimms
text: The king was sorry that for the sake of one he should lose all his faithful servants, wished that he had never set eyes on the tailor, and would willingly have been rid of him again.

author: Grimms
text: But he did not venture to give him his dismissal, for he dreaded lest he should strike him and all his people dead, and place himself on the royal throne.

author: Grimms
text: He thought about it for a long time, and at last found good counsel.

author: Grimms
text: He sent to the little tailor and caused him to be informed that as he was a great warrior, he had one request to make to him.

author: Grimms
text: In a forest of his country lived two giants, who caused great mischief with their robbing, murdering, ravaging, and burning, and no one could approach them without putting himself in danger of death.

author: Grimms
text: If the tailor conquered and killed these two giants, he would give him his only daughter to wife, and half of his kingdom as a dowry, likewise one hundred horsemen should go with him to assist him.

author: Grimms
text: "That would indeed be a fine thing for a man like me!" thought the little tailor.

author: Grimms
text: "One is not offered a beautiful princess and half a kingdom every day of one"s life!"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, yes," he replied, "I will soon subdue the giants, and do not require the help of the hundred horsemen to do it; he who can hit seven with one blow has no need to be afraid of two."

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor went forth, and the hundred horsemen followed him.

author: Grimms
text: When he came to the outskirts of the forest, he said to his followers: "Just stay waiting here, I alone will soon finish off the giants."

author: Grimms
text: Then he bounded into the forest and looked about right and left.

author: Grimms
text: After a while he perceived both giants.

author: Grimms
text: They lay sleeping under a tree, and snored so that the branches waved up and down.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor, not idle, gathered two pocketsful of stones, and with these climbed up the tree.

author: Grimms
text: When he was halfway up, he slipped down by a branch, until he sat just above the sleepers, and then let one stone after another fall on the breast of one of the giants.

author: Grimms
text: For a long time the giant felt nothing, but at last he awoke, pushed his comrade, and said: "Why are you knocking me?"

author: Grimms
text: "You must be dreaming," said the other, "I am not knocking you."

author: Grimms
text: They laid themselves down to sleep again, and then the tailor threw a stone down on the second.

author: Grimms
text: "What is the meaning of this?" cried the other "Why are you pelting me?"

author: Grimms
text: "I am not pelting you," answered the first, growling.

author: Grimms
text: They disputed about it for a time, but as they were weary they let the matter rest, and their eyes closed once more.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor began his game again, picked out the biggest stone, and threw it with all his might on the breast of the first giant.

author: Grimms
text: "That is too bad!" cried he, and sprang up like a madman, and pushed his companion against the tree until it shook.

author: Grimms
text: The other paid him back in the same coin, and they got into such a rage that they tore up trees and belaboured each other so long, that at last they both fell down dead on the ground at the same time.

author: Grimms
text: Then the little tailor leapt down.

author: Grimms
text: "It is a lucky thing," said he, "that they did not tear up the tree on which I was sitting, or I should have had to sprint on to another like a squirrel; but we tailors are nimble."

author: Grimms
text: He drew out his sword and gave each of them a couple of thrusts in the breast, and then went out to the horsemen and said: "The work is done; I have finished both of them off, but it was hard work!

author: Grimms
text: They tore up trees in their sore need, and defended themselves with them, but all that is to no purpose when a man like myself comes, who can kill seven at one blow."

author: Grimms
text: "But are you not wounded?" asked the horsemen.

author: Grimms
text: "You need not concern yourself about that," answered the tailor, "they have not bent one hair of mine."

author: Grimms
text: The horsemen would not believe him, and rode into the forest; there they found the giants swimming in their blood, and all round about lay the torn-up trees.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor demanded of the king the promised reward; he, however, repented of his promise, and again bethought himself how he could get rid of the hero.

author: Grimms
text: "Before you receive my daughter, and the half of my kingdom," said he to him, "you must perform one more heroic deed.

author: Grimms
text: In the forest roams a unicorn which does great harm, and you must catch it first."

author: Grimms
text: "I fear one unicorn still less than two giants.

author: Grimms
text: Seven at one blow, is my kind of affair."

author: Grimms
text: He took a rope and an axe with him, went forth into the forest, and again bade those who were sent with him to wait outside.

author: Grimms
text: He had not long to seek.

author: Grimms
text: The unicorn soon came towards him, and rushed directly on the tailor, as if it would gore him with its horn without more ado.

author: Grimms
text: "Softly, softly; it can"t be done as quickly as that," said he, and stood still and waited until the animal was quite close, and then sprang nimbly behind the tree.

author: Grimms
text: The unicorn ran against the tree with all its strength, and stuck its horn so fast in the trunk that it had not the strength enough to draw it out again, and thus it was caught.

author: Grimms
text: "Now, I have got the bird," said the tailor, and came out from behind the tree and put the rope round its neck, and then with his axe he hewed the horn out of the tree, and when all was ready he led the beast away and took it to the king.

author: Grimms
text: The king still would not give him the promised reward, and made a third demand.

author: Grimms
text: Before the wedding the tailor was to catch him a wild boar that made great havoc in the forest, and the huntsmen should give him their help.

author: Grimms
text: "Willingly," said the tailor, "that is child"s play!"

author: Grimms
text: He did not take the huntsmen with him into the forest, and they were well pleased that he did not, for the wild boar had several times received them in such a manner that they had no inclination to lie in wait for him.

author: Grimms
text: When the boar perceived the tailor, it ran on him with foaming mouth and whetted tusks, and was about to throw him to the ground, but the hero fled and sprang into a chapel which was near and up to the window at once, and in one bound out again.

author: Grimms
text: The boar ran after him, but the tailor ran round outside and shut the door behind it, and then the raging beast, which was much too heavy and awkward to leap out of the window, was caught.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor called the huntsmen thither that they might see the prisoner with their own eyes.

author: Grimms
text: The hero, however, went to the king, who was now, whether he liked it or not, obliged to keep his promise, and gave his daughter and the half of his kingdom.

author: Grimms
text: Had he known that it was no warlike hero, but a little tailor who was standing before him, it would have gone to his heart still more than it did.

author: Grimms
text: The wedding was held with great magnificence and small joy, and out of a tailor a king was made.

author: Grimms
text: After some time the young queen heard her husband say in his dreams at night: "Boy, make me the doublet, and patch the pantaloons, or else I will rap the yard-measure over your ears."

author: Grimms
text: Then she discovered in what state of life the young lord had been born, and next morning complained of her wrongs to her father, and begged him to help her to get rid of her husband, who was nothing else but a tailor.

author: Grimms
text: The king comforted her and said: "Leave your bedroom door open this night, and my servants shall stand outside, and when he has fallen asleep shall go in, bind him, and take him on board a ship which shall carry him into the wide world."

author: Grimms
text: The woman was satisfied with this; but the king"s armour-bearer, who had heard all, was friendly with the young lord, and informed him of the whole plot.

author: Grimms
text: "I"ll put a screw into that business," said the little tailor.

author: Grimms
text: At night he went to bed with his wife at the usual time, and when she thought that he had fallen asleep, she got up, opened the door, and then lay down again.

author: Grimms
text: The little tailor, who was only pretending to be asleep, began to cry out in a clear voice: "Boy, make me the doublet and patch me the pantaloons, or I will rap the yard-measure over your ears.

author: Grimms
text: I smote seven at one blow.

author: Grimms
text: I killed two giants, I brought away one unicorn, and caught a wild boar, and am I to fear those who are standing outside the room."

author: Grimms
text: When these men heard the tailor speaking thus, they were overcome by a great dread, and ran as if the wild huntsman were behind them, and none of them would venture anything further against him.

author: Grimms
text: So the little tailor was and remained a king to the end of his life.
